body:
_From @lukechurch on March 15, 2017 9:40_

In studies we've seen participants clicking around the structure of the project in IntelliJ to try and find their code, looking in the android, ios and build folders.

It would be helpful if there was an obvious separation between 'things they should edit a lot' and 'things which the systems needs that they should leave alone' were stronger. 
Alternatively if they never need to edit the other folders, perhaps we could hide them altogether?

_Copied from original issue: flutter/flutter#8784_

comment_data.body: @lukechurch : curious if you have any recommendations here.  Examples of places where this is done better?  (Not disagreeing mind you; just looking for guidance!)

@pq IIRC Ye Goode Olde Dart Editor did some things along this line, sorting some folders to the bottom?

I think Visual Studio separates 'files in project' from 'files in disk' and has the option of switching (https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/benwilli/2015/05/21/visual-studio-tip-8-adding-existing-files-with-show-all-files/) 

My recommendation somewhat depends on how often users need to know about all the android and iOS stuff. If it's basically never then I'd recommend hiding it and putting a 'show all files' somewhere in a menu.

If it's 'sometimes' then I'd recommend sorting the files and folders to the end and making them partially transparent.

Good recall @lukechurch.  The olde editor of yore did some sorting and hiding to make sense of all this.  I believe we can do similar things in IDEA but I'm not sure the details.  I do recall there are restrictions on what we can hide (folders: yes, files : no) see: https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/issues/630#issuecomment-272430576.

@alexander-doroshko : can you confirm whether we can control sort order?

I'm not aware of extension points that affect Project View sorting. There's one standard sorting action under gear, and I do not think the view is designed to be sorted alternatively.

If files in these folders are of no interest you can exclude these folders. As you know there's an option whether to show excluded folders or not in the Project View. Excluded files are considered to be outside of the project and are not indexed.

There are extension points that allow changing node presentation including icon, text, colors and all the rest. It is even possible to add or remove any kind of nodes to/from the Project View. Be careful if you go this way: you never can make 100% of users happy with unpredictable project tree.

> There are extension points that allow changing node presentation

Perhaps this would be a good way to go - to de-emphasize certain folders we likely didn't want users to edit in IntelliJ.

Circling back to this, let's talk about ideal presentations. Here's what we see today: For inspiration, here's what we see for a Java project: Minimally, we could emphasis the `lib` directory (as the `src` is in Java). Thoughts welcome!

#908 proposes this incremental improvement:

![screen shot 2017-04-12 at 12 11 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67586/24978945/4ecf8e46-1f87-11e7-8c4d-9012e727d4a8.png)

* emphasizes `lib` dir
* tags `.idea` as generated

Comments welcome!
Is it possible to automatically open the lib folder upon opening/creating a project? That would make it real obvious where your code is.
Good thinking.  When we create a project we do that.  (We open `main.dart`.)  We may not do that reliably for opened projects though.

That's what I did to the screenshot for the codelab - highlighted main.dart
in the left nav.
Good to be in sync...

On Wed, Apr 12, 2017 at 2:38 PM, Phil Quitslund <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Good thinking. When we create a project we do that. (We open main.dart.)
> We may not do that reliably for opened projects though.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/issues/824#issuecomment-293715260>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AWYL58D233rzlkWvNH3yNoRLFn0w7BgFks5rvUQ8gaJpZM4MeCjr>
> .
>

I like the idea of having `lib` node expanded and `main.dart` file focused in the Project View when opening a newly created project for the first time. This could be done by project generator - it could add the corresponding state to the generated `.idea/workspace.xml`. Of course on existing project opening, no magic should happen, IDE restores the previous state as it always does.

I don't like the idea of reusing 'source folder' icon for a folder that is not a source folder according to the IntelliJ project model. Unlikely it can greatly help newcomers who do not know icons meaning. OTOH experienced users may be confused by project model and presentation inconsistency. 
Also, suggested change affects non-Flutter Dart projects, but there sources are usually located in multiple folders: `lib`, `web`, `bin`, `tool`, `benchmark`, `example`, etc.

My $0.02.

As always, thanks for the $0.02 @alexander-doroshko!

My thinking is that the emphasis will help new users since it emphasizes where their source lives.  At a high level it feels very much like what's being done for source folders as captured in the IDEA model.  That said, it would be unfortunate to create any unnecessary confusion.  (Luckily this is something we can at least be mindful of when we do studies.)

My resistance to using another decoration is that it's just another thing and worry that it would be overwhelming especially when in practice the distinction is quite subtle.

Curious though if folks have other thoughts?

(As for folder opening and initial project selection, I think we're in agreement.)

@lukechurch @InMatrix @sethladd @mit-mit @devoncarew
Would it help to have the `lib/` folder be a source folder, from an IntelliJ perspective? Is this just some metadata for the module that we need to create on module creation?

Here is the current state:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13644170/27475719-78bc42aa-5806-11e7-9421-f5dec9affb82.png)

Looks like we got the lib folder highlighted @pq? Shall we close this bug?

milestone.description: Work triaged but not yet planned for a specific release.
milestone.title: Backlog

title: It's not obvious to new users where their code is in IntelliJ
